messageBody:
On Thu, 4 Sep 2003, Venkatesh Prasad Ranganath wrote:

> No, the question is when you have many phases that setup the data
> on which an analysis works, how do you unit test the analysis
> efficiently?

I'm essentially going to say the same thing as J. B. Rainsberger, but
I'm going to say it slightly differently, so perhaps this will be
helpful.

Don't do the phases that set up the data. Instead, create chunks of
"already-set-up" data, and test against those. This is, basically, layer
decoupling.

For example, I unit test a lot of servlets that make database calls.
They'll invoke a method in the Repository that will perform some sort of
database action and return a result: say, "get me an object representing
the user logged in at such-and-such an IP address."

Making this User object "for real" involves a lot of work, including
accessing two different databases. However, when unit testing, my
servlet, unbeknownst to it, is not using the Repository that digs around
in various databases and performs processing and whanot, but is using a
different Repository (with the same interface, of course) that simply
returns a fixed, mock object based on the IP address.

So when testing, I know that the repository will return an
"unregistered" user when asked who is logged in on 10.0.0.1, and a
"registered" user when asked who is logged in on 10.0.0.2. I put those
parameters into a servlet that is making decisions based on whether the
user is "registered" or "unregistered," and check that that the servlet
is doing the correct thing in each case.

This allows me to do the bare minimum of setup to get this working.
There's no database access at all. The Repository that's being invoked
for this is nowhere near fully functional, many of the methods just
throw an "I am not implemented" exception. The User object that's
returned is not even fully functional; a lot of its methods also return
an "I am not implemented" exception. The mock objects that I'm using do
just barely enough to let me test, and that's it.

This is the real power of object oriented programming: the ability
easily to substitute one object for another.

Note that this does require changes to your non-test code to work. In my
system, originally I could just call a static method to do the database
work. I now have an object (the Repository) with a couple of different
subclasses (the one that actually does the database stuff, and the test
version), and a mechanism for setting up a servlet or group of servlets
with the correct Repository depending on whether they're being tested or
are in production. This is a lot of extra code which contributes nothing
to my program in a production environment.

> It may take a long time to setup the data, hence, the
> code-test-refactor cycle will prove rather costly.

Right. Here's an example of reduction of data-setup time. It takes a lot
of steps to decide whether or not a user is really registered. But for
testing:

class TestRepository
implements Repository
{
User getUserOnIPAddress(IPAddress address)
{
if (IPAddress.valueOf("10.0.0.1").equals(address)) {
return new TestUser() {
boolean isRegistered() {
return false;
}
};
} else if (IPAddress.valueOf("10.0.0.2").equals(address)) {
return new TestUser() {
boolean isRegistered() {
return false;
}
};
}
return null;
}
}
